bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Alberto Recio, January 3, 1953

div1.p: Hench thanks Recio for his courtesies, including paying Hench's hotel bill, when Hench was in Cuba for the Camp Lazear dedication. He requests a copy of Recio's speech given at the ceremony. Hench suggests enclosing Building No. 1 and using part of the structure as a pubic health center.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Alberto Recio, January 3, 1953
div1.opener:
January 3, 1953
Dr. Alberto Recio
Director de Salubridad
Habana, Cuba
My dear Doctor Recio:
div1.p:
Permit me to express to you and to your colleagues, the patrons for the
preservation of Camp Lazear, my very sincere appreciation for the many
courtesies you extended to me and to the other Americans on the occasion
of our recent visit to Havana. The other American visitors were as de-
lighted as I with the whole affair. I have been asked to describe the
ceremony for the staff of the Mayo Clinic. I would appreciate it greatly
if you would send me at your earliest convenience (by airmail if at all
possible) a complete copy of the remarks you made at the dedication of
Camp Lazear. I noted a brief abstract of it in one of the newspapers
but I am anxious to have your complete speech.

You ask me to help you with regard to the wording to be placed in or outside
of the caseta. I am a little confused. I think you are planning to place near
the flag pole a bronze tablet identifying the spot but I think you also had
in mind framing and placing, either on the inside or outside wall of the
caseta, an additional inscription. I am not sure whether you asked me to
help with one or both. Nor am I sure how long you want the wording to be.
I would appreciate knowing and I would be glad to cooperate in any way
possible.

I was delighted to hear that you had in mind the possible development of a
further memorial at Camp Lazear. It would be wonderful indeed if the present
caseta could be enclosed for permanent security in a museum room which would
be attached to a large building which could serve as a living memorial to
Doctors Finlay, Reed and their associates and which might take the form of a
public health unit or other useful building for the public of that district.
I should be delighted indeed to help in any way possible. In the meantime,
you may wish to have copies of photographs and related documents to frame and hang
inside the caseta. I should be glad to collaborate with you and Doctor Nogueira
and make available to you some of the photographs which I have.

May I thank you, Doctor Recio, and also Doctor Nogueira, for your unexpected
kindness in paying my hotel bill. I had no expectation of such hospitality
and it was a great surprise but a very pleasant one. I remonstrated with
Doctor Nogueira as I certainly did not want my expenses to be taken out of
the fund for Camp Lazear. He assured me that it was not and that my hotel
bill was being paid for with money that had been intended for Mr. Hanberry.

I appreciate very greatly not only this courtesy but the thought behind it.
I have made many trips this year attending scientific meetings at my own
expense in addition to those sponsored by the Clinic. Therefore this extra
courtesy on your part is very deeply appreciated.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
P.S.: Permit me to send you herewith a reprint which describes the re-
discovery of Camp Lazear, see page 3.
